executive_summary: Primary constraint appears to be governance/reporting overhead that crowds out product discovery and focused delivery capacity. Despite healthy delivery capability (short lead times, short-lived branches, low MTTR, mid commit frequency, strong Westrum score), deployment frequency is low and a large share of time is spent in meetings, tech debt, and unplanned work. This pattern suggests a policy/management constraint (reporting to show control and possible release gating) rather than a technical one. Increasing time on understanding user needs and reducing control-oriented reporting would likely reduce unplanned work, improve change quality, and enable higher deployment frequency without compromising stability.

core_systemic_issues.issue: Control/reporting overhead limits discovery and focused delivery capacity
causes: Policy-driven emphasis on reporting to demonstrate control (CRT E1)
Time diversion away from understanding user needs (CRT E2)
High meeting load indicating coordination/control overhead
evidence: Low deployment frequency despite low lead time and low MTTR

core_systemic_issues.issue: Insufficient user understanding increases rework/unplanned work and contributes to moderate change failure rate
causes: Reactive work and unclear requirements leading to unplanned work
evidence: CRT E2: Insufficient time spent on understanding user needs

core_systemic_issues.issue: Release cadence/governance likely constrains throughput more than engineering flow
causes: Batching of releases or approval gates limiting frequency
Capacity fragmentation from reporting/meetings reduces ready, deployable changes
evidence: DORA: deployment frequency = low while lead time for change = low and MTTR = low
Extended metrics: branch_lifetime = low (short-lived branches) indicating healthy integration practice
Commit_frequency = medium (some flow exists but not translating into deploys)

core_systemic_issues.issue: Capacity fragmentation from meetings, tech debt, and interruptions lowers planned feature throughput
evidence: Time allocation: meetings 22%, tech debt 22%, unplanned 22%, feature development 19%
DORA: lead time low (when work is started, it flows), but overall throughput appears constrained by available focused time

leverage_points.rationale: CRT explicitly links reporting to reduced discovery time. Reducing non-value-adding reporting would free time for user understanding and focused work, likely improving change quality (lower CFR) and enabling more deployable changes without changing technical practices.

Low deployment frequency coexists with low lead time and low MTTR, indicating the system can safely ship more often. Adjusting cadence/approvals would allow existing engineering flow to convert to throughput.
Allocating more time to understand user needs addresses a root cause in the CRT and is likely to reduce unplanned work and functional defects, improving CFR and predictability.

High unplanned and meeting time fragments attention, suppressing feature throughput. Reducing interruptions and unnecessary coordination preserves the already-healthy flow (short branches, low lead time) and translates it into higher deployment frequency.

systemic_relationships: Reporting to show control (E1) → less time for discovery (E2) → more rework/unplanned work → more coordination/meetings → further time lost to feature delivery → fewer deployable changes → low deployment frequency.
Less discovery → misaligned changes → medium change failure rate; strong culture (Westrum 4) and good engineering practices mitigate impact via low MTTR.
Short branch lifetime + low lead time indicate efficient integration and delivery pipelines; constraint is upstream (policy/cadence and availability of well-shaped work), not engineering capability.
High unplanned work and tech debt compete with feature development, amplifying the effect of reporting/meeting overhead on throughput.
assumptions: "Low" lead time and MTTR are interpreted as favorable (short/fast); "low" deployment frequency is interpreted as undesirable given context.
Branch_lifetime "low" indicates short-lived branches (healthy); commit_frequency "medium" indicates moderate code flow.
Meeting time includes the reporting overhead referenced in CRT E1.
Unplanned work reflects interruptions/operational/reactive tasks rather than planned backlog items.
Westrum score of 4 indicates a generative/learning culture that can absorb change safely.
PBIs delivered per sprint per team is unavailable; conclusions about throughput rely on DORA and time allocation proxies.
analysis_confidence: Moderate. The CRT is minimal (two entities, one link), PBIs throughput is missing, and qualitative labels (low/medium) can vary by context. However, multiple signals consistently point to a policy/governance constraint rather than a technical one.
